claim: London gets more international arrivals than Paris.

supporting.text: London has consistently ranked as one of the top global cities for international tourism, with over 20 million international arrivals annually, surpassing Paris.

attacks.text: London has consistently ranked as one of the top global cities for international tourism, with over 20 million international arrivals annually, surpassing Paris.
Recent data from 2022 shows Paris had 21.6 million international arrivals, while London had 20.4 million, indicating Paris may have surpassed London.
The 2022 Paris surge was due to post-pandemic recovery bias, while London's numbers are more stable long-term.
London's numbers include transit passengers at Heathrow who don't actually visit the city, inflating its tourism figures.
Major airports like Charles de Gaulle also handle transit passengers, so this factor affects both cities comparably.
Paris dominates in cultural tourism metrics like museum visits, suggesting it may attract more genuine tourists despite arrival counts.

supporting.text: London's Heathrow Airport is one of the busiest airports in the world by international passenger traffic, significantly contributing to higher international arrivals compared to Paris.

attacks.text: London's Heathrow Airport is one of the busiest airports in the world by international passenger traffic, significantly contributing to higher international arrivals compared to Paris.
Paris has multiple major airports (Charles de Gaulle, Orly, and Beauvais), which collectively handle more international passenger traffic than Heathrow alone.
Heathrow's passenger traffic includes a significant portion of transit passengers who do not actually enter London, thus not counting as international arrivals.
Charles de Gaulle Airport also serves as a major transit hub, meaning not all its passenger traffic represents arrivals in Paris.
London's tourism industry is more globally marketed than Paris's, leading to higher intentional travel and thus more international arrivals.
Paris remains the most visited city in the world by international tourists, according to recent tourism reports, contradicting the claim about London.

supporting.text: The UK's capital benefits from being a major global financial and cultural hub, attracting more business and leisure travelers than Paris.

attacks.text: The UK's capital benefits from being a major global financial and cultural hub, attracting more business and leisure travelers than Paris.
Paris has a higher number of iconic tourist attractions, such as the Eiffel Tower and Louvre, which draw more leisure travelers globally.
France has historically been the world's most visited country, with Paris as its primary entry point, suggesting higher arrivals.
London's financial hub status primarily attracts business travelers, who are fewer in number compared to leisure travelers to Paris.
Recent Brexit-related travel restrictions may have reduced international arrivals to London compared to Paris.

supporting.text: London hosts a wider variety of international events and conferences annually, drawing more visitors from around the world compared to Paris.

attacks.text: London hosts a wider variety of international events and conferences annually, drawing more visitors from around the world compared to Paris.
Paris hosts more high-profile cultural events like Fashion Week and the French Open, which attract significant international visitors.
London's events are often business-focused, which may not necessarily translate to higher overall tourist numbers compared to Paris's leisure attractions.
Business travelers often have higher spending power and longer stays, contributing more to London's visitor statistics.
Paris has a more centralized tourism infrastructure, making it easier for visitors to access major attractions, potentially increasing its appeal.
London's public transport system is more extensive and efficient, facilitating easier movement for international visitors across the city.

supporting.text: Historical data from pre-pandemic years shows London leading Paris in international tourist arrivals, a trend that has continued post-pandemic recovery.

attacks.text: Historical data from pre-pandemic years shows London leading Paris in international tourist arrivals, a trend that has continued post-pandemic recovery.
Post-pandemic data from 2023 shows Paris overtaking London in international tourist arrivals due to stronger recovery in the luxury tourism sector.
The 2023 Paris surge was temporary, driven by one-time events like the Rugby World Cup, while London's visitor numbers show more stable long-term growth.
Methodological differences in counting arrivals (UK includes transit passengers while France doesn't) artificially inflate London's numbers.
Even when using standardized UNWTO methodology that excludes transit passengers, London still maintained a lead over Paris in 2019.
Paris benefits from stronger growth in Asian tourism markets which prioritize cultural landmarks over business travel that dominates London's arrivals.
